output.conclusion: This course provides a foundational understanding of VLSI design, equipping you with the knowledge to pursue more advanced topics and practical applications in the field.
output.introduction: Welcome to VLSI Design! This course will introduce you to the fundamental concepts of Very-Large-Scale Integration (VLSI) design, the process of creating integrated circuits (ICs) by combining billions of transistors on a single chip. We will cover basic concepts, design methodologies, and essential tools used in the VLSI design flow.

chapters.description: What is VLSI? History and evolution of VLSI. Moore's Law and its implications. Applications of VLSI in modern technology.
Transistors as switches. NMOS and PMOS transistors. CMOS logic gates: Inverter, NAND, NOR.
Voltage Transfer Characteristic (VTC). Noise margin. Propagation delay. Power dissipation.

modules.moduleTitle: Introduction to VLSI and Basic CMOS Circuits

chapters.description: Implementing Boolean functions using CMOS gates. Complex gates: AOI and OAI gates. Transmission gates.
Introduction to standard cell libraries. Layout considerations for standard cells. Stick diagrams.
Implementing simple combinational circuits: Adders, multiplexers, decoders.
Latches and Flip-Flops: SR latch, D latch, D flip-flop. Timing diagrams.
Registers and Counters. Finite State Machines (FSMs): State diagrams, state tables.
Introduction to SRAM and DRAM. Memory cell design.
Specification, design entry, synthesis, placement, routing, verification.
Overview of Verilog and VHDL. Basic syntax and data types.
Types of simulation: Functional, timing, and power simulation. Importance of verification.
Importance of design rules. Common design rules: Minimum width, spacing, and overlap.
Overview of layout editors. Basic layout operations: Placing, routing, and editing.
Power grid design. Clock distribution networks. Minimizing power consumption.
